Endoscopy GUIDED REMOVAL OF UPPER G.I. POLYP
AFP (Alpha Feto Protein)
investigationList.referenceRange: 0-40 ng/mL(nanogram/ml) or µgm/L(microgram/L) (µgm/L) for Men and nonpregnant women;10-150 nanogram/ml or microgram/L (µgm/L) for  Women 15-18 week pregnant;

investigationList.name: BHCG (Beta-Human Chorionic Gonadotropin)
investigationList.referenceRange: 0.5-2.9 negative; 2.9-5 Borderline; Positive >5.0; 500-10000 mIU/ml in 3-4 weeks; 1000-50000 mIU/ml in 4-5 weeks; 10000-100000 mIU/ml in 5-6 weeks; 15000-200000 mIU/ml in 6-8 weeks;10000-100000 mIU/ml in 8-12 weeks; intrauterine structure that must be seen : >100 (intrauterine sac), >7200 (Intra-uterine gestation sac with yolk sac), >12,800 (Intra-uterine gestational sac, yolk sac and fetal pole with HEART BEAT)

investigationList.name: PSA Total
investigationList.referenceRange: <40 years age: < or =2.0; 40-49 years age:< or =2.5;50-59 years age:< or =3.5; 60-69 years age: < or =4.5; 70-79 years age:< or =6.5>; or 80 years age:< or =7.2

investigationList.name: Troponin 1
investigationList.referenceRange: <0.01. Increased level is to be interpreted by physician

investigationList.name: BNP (Brain-Type Natriuretic Peptide)
investigationList.referenceRange: < 100 pg/mL(picogram/mililiter) - HF unlikely; >400 pg/mL - HF likely; 100-400 pg/mL - Use clinical judgment

investigationList.name: NT-pro BNP (Brain-Type Natriuretic Peptide)
investigationList.referenceRange: < 300 ng/mL (nanogram/mililiter) - HF unlikely; Age < 50 years: NT-proBNP >450 pg/mL - HF likely; Age 50-75 years: NT-proBNP >900 pg/mL – HF likely; Age >75 years: NT-proBNP >1800 – HF likely

ACT
investigationList.referenceRange: varies with test device used. Please check manufacturer's referrence.May vary between 80-160 seconds

investigationList.name: FDP (Fibrin Degradation Products)
investigationList.referenceRange: <10 µg/mL or less than 10 mg/L (SI units). An FDP level of more than 40 mg/mL is considered critical

investigationList.name: Fibrinogen
investigationList.referenceRange: Fibrinogen: 150-400 mg/dL. Fibrinogen antigen (range 149-353 mg/dL) is different

investigationList.name: Protein C
investigationList.referenceRange: The normal protein C level in a healthy adult is approximately 65-135 IU/dL. For a healthy term infant, the average value is 40 IU/dL, which will increase as the child ages, to approximately 60 IU/dL;Protein C deficiency is considered mild at plasma levels greater than 20 IU/dL but below the reference range. Moderate-to-severe deficiency is blood concentrations ranging from 1-20 IU/dL. Severe protein C deficiency is a value of less than 1 IU/dL or if protein C is not detectable.

investigationList.name: Protein S
investigationList.referenceRange: Males: Greater than 73 U/dL; Females: Greater than 63 U/dL

investigationList.name: CT Angiogram of Abdominal Aorta with Lower Limb Arteries
CT Angiogram of Thoracic Aorta and Arch of Aorta
CT Angiogram of Upper Limb Arteries
CT Aortogram from Neck and Femoral Head
CT Chest and CT guided FNAC
CT KUB (kidney, ureter, bladder regions) Without Contrast
CT KUB (kidney, ureter, bladder regions) With Contrast
Carbamazepine
investigationList.referenceRange: The therapeutic reference range of carbamazepine is 4-12 mg/L. The minimum toxic level is 10 mg/kg. The toxic concentration/critical laboratory value is greater than 30-40 mg/L

investigationList.name: Cyclosporine
investigationList.referenceRange: Most individuals display optimal response to cyclosporine with trough whole blood levels 100 to 400 ng/mL. Preferred therapeutic ranges may vary by transplant type, protocol, and comedications. Therapeutic ranges are based on specimens drawn at trough (ie, immediately before the next scheduled dose)

investigationList.name: Digoxin
investigationList.referenceRange: Therapeutic serum digoxin levels range from 0.5–2 ng/mL. Serum levels may be drawn 6–8 hr after a dose is administered, although they are usually drawn immediately before the next dose.

investigationList.name: Phenobarbital
investigationList.referenceRange: There is no exact relationship between the concentration of phenobarbital in the plasma and its therapeutic effects, however, plasma levels of 10-35 µg/mL are recommended for seizure management

investigationList.name: Phenytoin
investigationList.referenceRange: Phenytoin doses are usually selected to attain therapeutic plasma total phenytoin concentrations of 10 to 20 µg/mL

investigationList.name: Tacrolimus
investigationList.referenceRange: Most individuals display optimal response to Tacrolimus with trough whole blood levels of 5.0 to 15.0 ng/mL. Preferred therapeutic ranges may vary by transplant type, protocol, and comedications. Therapeutic ranges are based on samples drawn at trough

investigationList.name: Valproic Acid
investigationList.referenceRange: The therapeutic range for Valproic acid (total) is 50-125 µg/mL. The toxic level is greater than 150 µg/mL. The therapeutic range for valproic acid (free) is 6-22 µg/mL. The toxic level is greater than 50 µg/mL; above this threshold concentration, the binding sites on plasma albumin begin to become saturated.

investigationList.name: DUPLEX STUDY of VESSELS of Abdominal Aorta
DUPLEX STUDY of VESSELS of Kidney
DUPLEX STUDY of VESSELS of Liver

DUPLEX STUDY of VESSELS of Scrotum
DUPLEX STUDY of VESSELS of Theigh Left
DUPLEX STUDY of VESSELS of Theigh Right
Aldolase
investigationList.referenceRange: The specific ranges for an abnormal test may vary slightly by laboratory, and there are slight differences between normal levels for men and women. In general, normal results range from 1.0 to 7.5 units per liter

investigationList.name: ERCP and Extraction of Ascaris from Billiary tree & Pancreatic duct
Plasma Glucose (Fasting)
investigationList.referenceRange: <5.5 mmol in non-diabetic, 5.5- 6.9 impaired Glucose Tolerance, >7 diabetic

investigationList.name: Plasma Glucose (Random)
investigationList.referenceRange: <5.5 mmol/L in non-diabetic, 5.5- 11 mmol/L impaired Glucose Tolerance, >11 mmol/L is diabetic

investigationList.name: Red blood cells (RBC)
investigationList.referenceRange: For men: approximately 4.7 to 6.1 million cells/ul (microliter). The normal range in women range from 4.2 to 5.4 million cells/ul.

investigationList.name: Reticulocyte count
investigationList.referenceRange: 20-84 10 to the power 9 /L; when expressed as percentage of Red Blood Cell 0.5% to 2.5% in adults and 2% to 6% in infants.

investigationList.name: ACTH
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal ranges for ACTH are fairly broad and like cortisol levels are time-dependent. They also vary from assay to assay. A typical normal range for an 8AM sample using the new assays is 10 to 50 picograms per milliliter (pg/ml); levels are usually less than 20 pg/ml at 4 PM and less than 5-10 pg/ml at midnight.

investigationList.name: FT3 ( Free T3)
investigationList.referenceRange: 260-480 pg/dL, or 4-7.4 pmol/L in adult. usually not measured in children

investigationList.name: TT3 ( Total triiodothyronine)
investigationList.referenceRange: 80-220 ng/dL in adults and 125-250 ng/dL in children

investigationList.name: TSH
investigationList.referenceRange: 0.4 to 4.0 milli-international units per liter. If you're already being treated for a thyroid disorder, the normal range is 0.5 to 3.0 milli-international units per liter.

investigationList.name: Estradiol
investigationList.referenceRange: The reference range of estradiol in men is 10-40 pg/mL. The reference range estradiol in women varies by menstrual cycle and menopausal status, as follows: Before menopause, estradiol levels are widely variable throughout the menstrual cycle: Mid-follicular phase: 27-123 pg/mL

investigationList.name: Growth Hormone
investigationList.referenceRange: Random growth hormone (GH) levels in a healthy person range as follows: Men: < 5 ng/mL or < 226 pmol/L. Women: < 10 ng/mL or < 452 pmol/L. Children: 0-20 ng/mL or 0-904 pmol/L.

investigationList.name: Progesterone
investigationList.referenceRange: Female (pre-ovulation): less than 1 ng/mL; Female (mid-cycle): 5 to 20 ng/mL; Male: less than 1 ng/mL; Postmenopausal: less than 1 ng/mL; Pregnancy 1st trimester: 11.2 to 90.0 ng/mL; Pregnancy 2nd trimester: 25.6 to 89.4 ng/mL; Pregnancy 3rd trimester: 48 to 150 to 300 or more ng/mL

investigationList.name: Prolactin
investigationList.referenceRange: Males: 2 to 18 ng/mL. Nonpregnant females: 2 to 29 ng/mL. Pregnant women: 10 to 209 ng/mL

investigationList.name: Testosterone
investigationList.referenceRange: Men: 270-1070 ng/dL (9-38 nmol/L). Women: 15-70 ng/dL (0.52-2.4 nmol/L. Children (depends on sex and age at puberty): 2-20 ng/dL or 0.07-0.7 nmol/L

investigationList.name: FSH
investigationList.referenceRange: Before puberty: 0 to 4.0 mIU/ml. During puberty: 0.3 to 10.0 mIU/ml. Women who are still menstruating: 4.7 to 21.5 mIU/ml. After menopause: 25.8 to 134.8 mIU/ml.

investigationList.name: LH
investigationList.referenceRange: women in the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle: 1.9 to 12.5 IU/L. women at the peak of the menstrual cycle: 8.7 to 76.3 IU/L. women in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle: 0.5 to 16.9 IU/L. pregnant women: less than 1.5 IU/L.

investigationList.name: AntiNucleur Antigen (ANA)
investigationList.referenceRange: The frequency of positivity on ANA screening test (on Hep-2 cells) is as follows: Mixed connective tissue disease: 100%; Drug-induced lupus erythematosus: 100%; Systemic lupus erythematosus: 95%-100%; Sjögren Syndrome: 80%; Scleroderma: 60%-95%; Polymyositis-dermatomyositis: 49%-74%; Rheumatoid arthritis: 40%-60%

investigationList.name: ASO Titre
investigationList.referenceRange: An antistreptolysin titer (ASO) greater than 166 Todd units (or >200 IU) is considered a positive test. This upper limit of normal may vary from lab to lab and by age, with it being higher in school-aged children.

investigationList.name: C3
investigationList.referenceRange: The normal range for a complement C3 blood test is 80 to 160 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 0.8 to 1.6 grams per liter (g/L).

investigationList.name: C4
investigationList.referenceRange: The normal range for a complement C4 blood test is 16 to 48 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 0.16 to 0.48 grams per liter (g/L)

investigationList.name: D-dimer
investigationList.referenceRange: A normal D-dimer result (< or =250 ng/mL DDU; < or =0.50  µg/L FEU)

investigationList.name: IgA
investigationList.referenceRange: Age 0-1 years: 0-83 mg/dL; Age 1-3 years: 20-100 mg/dL; Age 4-6 years: 27-195 mg/dL; Age 7-9 years: 34-305 mg/dL; Age 10-11 years: 53-204 mg/dL; Age 12-13 years: 58-358 mg/dL; Age 14-15 years: 47-249 mg/dL; Age 16-19 years: 61-348 mg/dLOlder than 19 years: 70-400 mg/dL

investigationList.name: IgG
investigationList.referenceRange: Age 0-1 years: 231-1411 mg/dL; Age 1-3 years: 453-916 mg/dL; Age 4-6 years: 504-1464 mg/dL; Age 7-9 years: 572-1474 mg/dL; Age 10-11 years: 698-1560 mg/dL; Age 12-13 years: 759-1549 mg/dL; Age 14-15 years: 716-1711 mg/dL; Age 16-19 years: 549-1584 mg/dL; Older than 19 years: 700-1600 mg/dL

investigationList.name: IgM
investigationList.referenceRange: Age 0-1 years: 0-145 mg/dL; Age 1-3 years: 19-146 mg/dL; Age 4-6 years: 24-210 mg/dL; Age 7-9 years: 31-208 mg/dL; Age 10-11 years: 31-179 mg/dL; Age 12-13 years: 35-239 mg/dL; Age 14-15 years: 15-188 mg/dL; Age 16-19 years: 23-259 mg/dLOlder than 19 years: 40-230 mg/dL

investigationList.name: RF Test
investigationList.referenceRange: Any result with values 14 IU/ml or above is considered abnormally high, elevated, or positive.

investigationList.name: HDL Cholesterol
investigationList.referenceRange: If HDL-C is less than 40 mg/dL (1.04 mmol/L), there is an increased risk of heart disease that is independent of other risk factors, including the LDL-C level. A level of HDL-C between 40 and 45 mg/dL (1.04-1.17 mmol/L) is borderline

investigationList.name: LDL Cholesterol
investigationList.referenceRange: Less than 100 mg/dL (2.59 mmol/L) — Optimal;  100-129 mg/dL (2.59-3.34 mmol/L) — Near optimal, above optimal; 130-159 mg/dL (3.37-4.12 mmol/L) — Borderline high; 160-189 mg/dL (4.15-4.90 mmol/L) — High; Greater than 189 mg/dL (4.90 mmol/L) — Very high

investigationList.name: Triglycerides
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal — Less than 150 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or less than 1.7 millimoles per liter (mmol/L); Borderline high — 150 to 199 mg/dL (1.8 to 2.2 mmol/L); High — 200 to 499 mg/dL (2.3 to 5.6 mmol/L)

investigationList.name: Albumin Globulin Ratio
investigationList.referenceRange: The normal A/G ratio is 0.8-2.0. The A/G ratio can be decreased in response to a low albumin or to elevated globulins.

investigationList.name: Globulin
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal value ranges are: Serum globulin: 2.0 to 3.5 g/dL (grams per deciliter) IgM component: 75 to 300 mg/dL (milligrams per deciliter) IgG component: 650 to 1850 mg/dL

investigationList.name: LDH
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal LDH levels range from 140 units per liter (U/L) to 280 U/L or 2.34 mkat/L to 4.68 mkat/L.

investigationList.name: S Total Protein
investigationList.referenceRange: 6.4-8.3 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 64-83 grams per liter (g/L)

investigationList.name: SGPT(ALT), SGOT(AST), Alk. Phosphatase, S. Bilirubin, INR, Albumin
SGPT(ALT), SGOT(AST), Alk. Phosphatase, S. Bilirubin
eGFR
investigationList.referenceRange: >90 is considered as normal. eGFR decreases with age. An eGFR below 60 mL/min/1.73m2 suggests that some kidney damage has occurred.Following is a guideline for severity. Stage 1 : 90 or above; Stage 2: 60-89; Stage 3: 30-69. stagge 4 15-29; stage 5 <15.

investigationList.name: Na, K, Cl, Urea, Creatinine, eGFR
Osmolality (Urine)
investigationList.referenceRange: The normal 24-hour urine osmolality is, on average, 500-800 mOsm/kg of water. Random urine osmolality should average 300-900 mOsm/kg of water. After 12-14 hours of fluid intake restriction, the urine osmolality should exceed 850 mOsm/kg of water.

investigationList.name: Urine Protein Creatinine Ratio (ACR), Spot
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal daily (24 hour) urine albumin excretion is less than 30 mg in adults. If the 24 hour urine albumin excretion results are between 30-300 mg it becomes defined as microalbuminuria (MAU)

investigationList.name: UTP, 24 hour
investigationList.referenceRange: The normal value is less than 100 milligrams per day or less than 10 milligrams per deciliter of urine.

investigationList.name: Ultrasound of KUB with Prostate & Residual Volume
Ultrasound of Pregnancy Profile with anomaly Scan
Ultrasound of Pregnancy Profile with Chromosomal Scan
Ultrasound guided ALCOHOL INJECTION of HEPATOMA
Ammonia
investigationList.referenceRange: for adults, anything between 9.5 and 49 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL) is considered normal. The levels of ammonia are considered normal in children if they are between 40 and 80mcg/dL. In newborns, the levels of ammonia should be between 90 and 150 mcg/dL.

investigationList.name: Feritin
investigationList.referenceRange: 24 to 336 nanograms per milliliter in men. 11 to 307 nanograms per milliliter in women

investigationList.name: Folate
investigationList.referenceRange: The reference range of the plasma folate level varies by age, as follows: Adults: 2-20 ng/mL, or 4.5-45.3 nmol/L; Children: 5-21 ng/mL, or 11.3-47.6 nmol/L; Infants: 14-51 ng/mL, or 31.7-115.5 nmol/L

investigationList.name: Folic Acid
investigationList.referenceRange: The reference range of the plasma folate level varies by age, as follows: Adults: 2-20 ng/mL, or 4.5-45.3 nmol/L; Children: 5-21 ng/mL, or 11.3-47.6 nmol/L; Infants: 14-51 ng/mL, or 31.7-115.5 nmol/L

investigationList.name: Serum Iron
investigationList.referenceRange: The serum iron reference range is 55–160 µg/dL in men and40–155 µg/dL in women.

investigationList.name: Serum Uric Acid
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal Uric acid levels are 2.4-6.0 mg/dL (female) and 3.4-7.0 mg/dL (male).

investigationList.name: Vitamin D(25 OH)
investigationList.referenceRange: A level of 20 nanograms/milliliter to 50 ng/mL is considered adequate for healthy people. A level less than 12 ng/mL indicates vitamin D deficiency.

investigationList.name: X-RAY Ba meal of Stomach and duodenum
X-RAY IVU with Post micturation Flim
Plasma Glucose (Random)/RBS
investigationList.referenceRange: <5.5 mmol/L in non-diabetic, 5.5- 11 mmol/L impaired Glucose Tolerance, >11 mmol/L is diabetic

investigationList.name: Plasma Glucose (Random)/RBS after iftar
investigationList.referenceRange: <5.5 mmol/L in non-diabetic, 5.5- 11 mmol/L impaired Glucose Tolerance, >11 mmol/L is diabetic

investigationList.referenceRange: <0.01. Increased level is to be interpreted by physician

investigationList.name: eGFR
investigationList.referenceRange: >90 is considered as normal. eGFR decreases with age. An eGFR below 60 mL/min/1.73m2 suggests that some kidney damage has occurred.Following is a guideline for severity. Stage 1 : 90 or above; Stage 2: 60-89; Stage 3: 30-69. stagge 4 15-29; stage 5 <15.

name: Cervical Swab for Gram Stain, R/E

name: FNAC OF BOTH SIDE THYROID NODULE

investigationList.name: FNAC OF BOTH SIDE THYROID NODULE
ACTH
investigationList.referenceRange: Normal ranges for ACTH are fairly broad and like cortisol levels are time-dependent. They also vary from assay to assay. A typical normal range for an 8AM sample using the new assays is 10 to 50 picograms per milliliter (pg/ml); levels are usually less than 20 pg/ml at 4 PM and less than 5-10 pg/ml at midnight.

investigationList.name: FT3 ( Free T3)
investigationList.referenceRange: 260-480 pg/dL, or 4-7.4 pmol/L in adult. usually not measured in children

investigationList.name: TT3 ( Total triiodothyronine)
investigationList.referenceRange: 80-220 ng/dL in adults and 125-250 ng/dL in children

investigationList.name: Estradiol
investigationList.referenceRange: The reference range of estradiol in men is 10-40 pg/mL. The reference range estradiol in women varies by menstrual cycle and menopausal status, as follows: Before menopause, estradiol levels are widely variable throughout the menstrual cycle: Mid-follicular phase: 27-123 pg/mL

investigationList.name: Growth Hormone
investigationList.referenceRange: Random growth hormone (GH) levels in a healthy person range as follows: Men: < 5 ng/mL or < 226 pmol/L. Women: < 10 ng/mL or < 452 pmol/L. Children: 0-20 ng/mL or 0-904 pmol/L.

investigationList.name: Progesterone
investigationList.referenceRange: Female (pre-ovulation): less than 1 ng/mL; Female (mid-cycle): 5 to 20 ng/mL; Male: less than 1 ng/mL; Postmenopausal: less than 1 ng/mL; Pregnancy 1st trimester: 11.2 to 90.0 ng/mL; Pregnancy 2nd trimester: 25.6 to 89.4 ng/mL; Pregnancy 3rd trimester: 48 to 150 to 300 or more ng/mL

investigationList.name: Prolactin
investigationList.referenceRange: Males: 2 to 18 ng/mL. Nonpregnant females: 2 to 29 ng/mL. Pregnant women: 10 to 209 ng/mL

investigationList.name: Testosterone
investigationList.referenceRange: Men: 270-1070 ng/dL (9-38 nmol/L). Women: 15-70 ng/dL (0.52-2.4 nmol/L. Children (depends on sex and age at puberty): 2-20 ng/dL or 0.07-0.7 nmol/L

investigationList.name: TSH
investigationList.referenceRange: 0.4 to 4.0 milli-international units per liter. If you're already being treated for a thyroid disorder, the normal range is 0.5 to 3.0 milli-international units per liter.
